{{Short description|American country music trio}} {{other uses|Three of hearts (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = 3 of Hearts | image = | alt = | caption = | alias = Three of Hearts | origin = [[Fort Worth, Texas]], United States | genre = [[country music|Country]] | years_active = 2001–2005 | label = [[RCA Records Nashville|RCA Nashville]] | past_members = {{Unbulleted list|Blaire Stroud|Katie McNeill|Deserea Wasdin}} }} '''3 of Hearts''' was an American [[country music]] trio composed of Blaire Stroud, Katie McNeill, and Deserea Wasdin, all natives of [[Fort Worth, Texas]]. Signed to [[RCA Records Nashville|RCA Nashville]] in 2001, the trio released its debut album in July of that year. Two of its singles entered the U.S. ''Billboard'' [[Hot Country Singles & Tracks]] charts, as did their rendition of "[[The Christmas Shoes (song)#Cover versions and other media|The Christmas Shoes]]." ==Biography== Blaire Stroud, Katie McNeill, and Deserea Wasdin first sang at a funeral; They were also students at [[L.D. Bell High School]]; later, they cut a [[demo tape]] which was eventually sent to [[RCA Records Nashville|RCA Nashville]], who signed the trio to a record deal in 2000. They recorded the song, "Just Might Change Your Life", which appeared in the film and on the soundtrack for the film, "Where the Heart Is", in the Summer of 2000. 3 of Hearts also embarked on a tour sponsored by ''[[Seventeen (American magazine)|Seventeen]]'' magazine, in which the trio performed at shopping malls and promoted prom-related fashion trends.{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p484989|pure_url=yes}} |title=3 of Hearts biography |access-date=2007-12-26 |last=Cohoon |first=Rick |work=[[Allmusic]]}} Their debut album, also titled ''3 of Hearts'', was released in March 2001. Two of its singles ("Love Is Enough" and "Arizona Rain") entered the U.S. ''Billboard'' [[Hot Country Singles & Tracks]] charts, peaking at No. 43 and No. 59 respectively. However, 3 of Hearts did not enter the Top 40 on the country music charts until early 2002, when their rendition of "[[The Christmas Shoes (song)|The Christmas Shoes]]" reached a peak of No. 39. ==Discography== ===Studio albums=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! rowspan="2" style="width:8em;"| Title ! rowspan="2" style="width:15em;"| Album details ! colspan="1"| Peak positions |- style="font-size:smaller;" ! width="40"| [[Top Country Albums|US Country]]
